channel.title: Budget Build Improvements?
channel.description:
http://pcpartpicker.com/p/yWTW8d
Any improvements I can change to this but not go over $1,200.
Only used for gaming really.

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @jummppy jummppy
item.description:
@jummppy wrote:

I would buy cheaper ram you don’t need crossair. Get a motherboard that’s a little cheaper, then invest the money you just saved into an i7 processor.

Read full topic

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

You could dual-boot a SSD and HDD, and use this 250GB SSD http://www.ebay.com/itm/331517376239 for general use such as programming, runescape and whatever else, while using a 3 or 4TB HDD for steam games.

Read full topic

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

[quote=“rmark45matsu, post:5, topic:551047”]http://pcpartpicker.com/p/RvFdYJ

As other users pointed out here, the h100i has no true benefits other than being “cool”. An air cooler can put out similar performance for cheaper.[/quote]
So this computer build would be a much better build than the one I posted?

In regards to the SSD, I forgot to add one in.

Bottom Line: I want to be able to do a lot of multitasking (movies, music, possible programming) and play runescape + other steam games on max graphics. Also want to build something that will be ‘good’ in the future.

Reason: My current computer is old, outdated and a piece of sh*t.

So if you could point me in the best direction for that with a $1,200 budget (no more than) that’d be awesome.

Read full topic

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @rmark45matsu rmark45matsu
item.description:
@rmark45matsu wrote:

http://pcpartpicker.com/p/RvFdYJ

As other users pointed out here, the h100i has no true benefits other than being “cool”. An air cooler can put out similar performance for cheaper.

Read full topic

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

How can you build a new PC and not put an SSD in it…

H100i not necessary, I have the H80i and it’s really nothing special, only key advantage is that it’s much smaller than any fan heatsink, if you were looking to save a bit of cash you could go for a fan alternative, or cheaper still, stick with the stock CPU cooler, nothing wrong with that, ran it on my i7 3770k/GTX 680 build for a good few months.

Read full topic

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

3TB Barracuda’s have a terrible failure rate Surprisingly, the 4TB are actually a lot more reliable. Get another HDD, but more importantly get a small SSD to store the OS, it’s honestly the cheapest way to get a huge amount of “everyday use” performance out of a machine.

Read full topic

item.title: Budget Build Improvements?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

First off, I don’t claim to actually know anything.

You’re wasting money on that motherboard. The only benefit to buying such an expensive motherboard is the overclocking potential, crossfire support, and maybe some other things, but that’s foolish with the CPU you’re buying. Drop the motherboard down to an appropriate $40-$60 one and upgrade the processor to an Intel i7 4770k. Or, you can budget even moreso and get the AMD FX-9590 which actually beats the 4770k for less than $200. Wow. Though, it’s not necessarily safe to compare an AMD 8-core processor to an Intel 4-core processor because the performance-per-core is probably significantly better on the Intel processor. It really depends on how the CPUs were benchmarked.

You can probably get a cheaper cooling too. I have a $70 liquid cooler for my AMD FX 8350 and it’s cool and quiet. Although I never overclock it, the cooler is apparently designed to handle overclocking temperatures. I guess it depends what your plans are.

Read full topic
